MS/591/4/5
ROYAL SOCIETY REC<sup>D<\sup> 23 OCT 1908
H.M.S. "BULWARK" <s>at Bantry<\s> Channel Fleet.
10th October 1908. 
Dear Sir Archibald Ge<s>a<\s>ikie, 
As the Meteorological results 
of the National Antarctic Expedition are being published 
by the Royal Society I feel called upon to bring to your 
official notice the fact that the volume already produced 
contains remarks and deductions to which I and other 
members of the Expedition take strong exception. 
Statements are made in the preface and 
elsewhere which assert or imply a wholly unmerited measure 
of defaut on the part of those responsible for the 
instruments and their use. The evidence of fact is 
partially considered, certain facts are ignored and the 
summarized results of observations are misrepresented. 
Before treating this matter in detail I 
would remark that the proofs of the volume were not seen 
by me or by any member of the Expedition before publication 
nor were the doubts formulated in them brought to our 
notice. Further the suggestion made in the preface that 
Officers of the Expedition were largely consulted with 
reference to specific points is not in accordance with 
fact. 
In dealing with the first paragraph of Dr 
Shaw's remarks headed 'Miscarriage of Instructions' 
(page VI) I put my comments in the for of questions
